newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Second operation seen for wounded Tajik leader.
newsitem.headline: Second operation seen for wounded Tajik leader.

text.p: Tajik President Imomali Rakhmonov, recovering from an attempt on his life, will have to undergo a second operation to remove all the shrapnel from a leg wound, the Tajik authorities said on Thursday.
An official in Rakhmonov's administration was unable to say when the new surgery on the president's right leg would take place.
"Surgeons operated for about an hour but they failed to remove all the shrapnel," said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Presidential spokesman Zafar Saidov said two people were killed and 72 were injured in the attack, which occurred when Rakhmonov visited the northern town of Khudjand on Wednesday.

Rakhmonov, 45, had a grenade thrown at his feet as he got out of a car. He was wounded in the legs but was able to limp down the steps from his aircraft when he returned to the capital Dushanbe late on Wednesday.
The official said Rakhmonov would not work for a week. "The president's health is normal but he must rest for a week," he said.

Tajikistan, a former Soviet republic, is still reeling from a four-year civil war in which tens of thousands of people died. Armed groups still roam the mountain state, which borders Afghanistan and China.

The government has condemned the attack as a "terrorist act" but has so far not blamed any one group for the attempt on Rakhmonov's life. "This (attack) was a struggle for power," was all Saidov would say.
A spokesman for Tajikistan's armed Islamic opposition, Rakhmonov's main foe in the civil war, told Reuters the group had had nothing to do with the attack.
A source at the National Revival of Tajikistan bloc, part of the republic's so-called "third" political force and based around Khudjand, also denied any involvement.

"This was not a political action but a criminal one," the source said. The bloc was excluded from a power-sharing arrangement tentatively agreed by the government and the Islamic opposition in February.
Diplomats and opposition sources say the attack could be revenge for the government's violent crushing of a prison riot in Khudjand earlier this month, which left 20 dead.

The riot leaders and Rakhmonov's would-be assassin, arrested on Wednesday immediately after the attack, was said by the authorities to have been involved in an anti-government demonstration in May last year.
